questions.text: Twelve hours after undergoing an exploratory laparotomy for a perforated duodenal ulcer, a 36-year-old man has shortness of breath. He has asthma well-controlled with an albuterol inhaler. His father died of lung cancer at 62 years of age. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 14 years. He does not drink alcohol. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. Examination shows reduced breath sounds over the left lung base. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. There is a clean, dry surgical incision over the midline of the abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. The calves are soft and nontender. His hemoglobin concentration is 12.9 g/dL, leukocyte count is 10,600/mm3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest in supine position is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with an asthma exacerbation can develop acute dyspnea. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as a dry cough, prolonged expiratory phase with crackles, bilaterally (not unilaterally) decreased breath sounds, and tachypnea. Chest x-ray during an asthma exacerbation can be normal or show signs of pulmonary hyperinflation (e.g., hyperlucent lung fields). Although this patient has asthma, the absence of these findings makes an exacerbation of this condition an unlikely cause of his symptoms.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (PA view)

Large lung volumes (green outline and arrows) are accompanied by intercostal space widening (examples indicated by red arrows) and diaphragmatic flattening, indicating hyperinflation.

B) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of gastric contents during perioperative procedures (e.g., intubation and extubation) can lead to pneumonitis, which causes acute dyspnea and airspace opacification on chest x-ray. However, this condition typically develops within minutes to hours after the aspiration event. Moreover, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of pneumonitis, which include a cough that is productive of pink sputum, wheezing, crackles, and fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia can cause postoperative dyspnea and an opacity restricted to one pulmonary lobe on chest x-ray. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of pneumonia, which include fever, chills, a cough that is productive of purulent sputum, crackles, and bronchial breath sounds.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA and lateral views) of a patient with pneumonia

There is heterogeneous right upper lobe consolidation (green overlay) with air bronchograms (examples of bronchial walls indicated by white lines). The major (white dashed line) and minor fissures (red dashed lines) are elevated from normal position as a result of accompanying atelectasis. No hilar enlargement or pleural effusion is seen.

The differential diagnosis for airspace consolidation considers the radiographic appearance, associated findings (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pleural effusion), and patient history and symptoms. Pneumonia, hemorrhage, edema, tumor, and protein can all present as consolidation on a chest radiograph.

Green line: aortic arch margin; LL: lower lobe; ML: middle lobe; UL: upper lobe

D) INCORRECT:

Patients who have recently undergone surgery have an increased risk of developing venous thromboembolic conditions such as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism due to several risk factors, which include prolonged immobilization and endothelial damage. Pulmonary embolism can cause acute dyspnea, but this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as chest pain, cough, jugular venous distension, and manifestations of deep vein thrombosis (e.g., erythema, edema, and tenderness of the leg).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pleuritic chest pain

A peripheral opacity (Hampton hump; green overlay) obscures the adjacent margin of the right hemidiaphragm. A Hampton hump is subpleural and is caused by pulmonary hemorrhage or infarction. The appearance is often wedge-shaped; however, it can alternatively be dome-shaped, if the apex is spared as a result of collateral bronchial arterial blood flow.

The differential diagnosis includes pneumonia and malignancy. Of note, the greater distance between the spinous processes and the medial edge of the clavicle on the right compared to the left indicates that the patient is rotated slightly to the right. The distances will be nearly equal when a patient is not rotated, whereas widening will be seen on the side to which a patient is rotated.

Dashed lines: margins of medial clavicles; White line and ellipses: spinous processes

E) CORRECT:

Atelectasis is one of the most common postoperative complications (especially after chest or abdominal surgery) and typically develops within 72 hours after surgery. Atelectasis can cause acute dyspnea if many alveoli are affected. Additional manifestations can include chest pain, tachycardia, and cyanosis. Chest x-ray of patients with atelectatic lungs typically shows a homogeneous opacification that corresponds to the area of lung collapse as seen in this patient.

The risk of postoperative atelectasis can be decreased by encouraging deep breathing exercises and early mobilization. Smoking should be avoided for 6–8 weeks prior to surgery.
Image Description:

1. Obstructive atelectasis: foreign body aspiration results in airflow obstruction, poor ventilation, and atelectasis.

2. Non-obstructive atelectasis:
A) Compression atelectasis: A pleural effusion causes increased intrathoracic pressure actively forcing air out of the alveoli.
B) Relaxation atelectasis: A pneumothorax disrupts the contact between the visceral and parietal pleurae, resulting in passive atelectasis.
C) Cicatrization atelectasis: Generalized parenchymal fibrosis impairs full expansion of the right lung.
D) Adhesive atelectasis: Increased surface tension due to a deficiency of surfactant leads to generalized alveolar collapse.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with decompensated heart failure can develop acute dyspnea due to pulmonary edema. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as a cough, crackles, wheezing, cyanosis, and edematous, cold, clammy skin. Moreover, though heart failure can cause a pleural effusion on chest x-ray, the resulting opacities typically develop bilaterally.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view)

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (hatched green overlay) and the perihilar air space opacities (green overlay) have a bat wing, or butterfly, configuration. Linear interstitial opacities representing Kerley A lines (orange dashed lines) radiate from the hila to the apices and Kerley B lines (white dashed lines) are seen in the lateral mid zones. The costophrenic angles are blunted (arrows) from bilateral pleural effusions.

These features are characteristically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

G) INCORRECT:

Pneumothorax can cause acute dyspnea and diminished breath sounds over the affected lung field. However, this patient does not have other typical manifestations of this condition such as unilateral, stabbing, and pleuritic chest pain. Moreover, chest x-ray of patients with a pneumothorax shows a visible visceral pleural line with absent lung markings and increased radiolucency in the area of lung collapse.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A thin white line represents the visceral pleura of the left lung (dotted line). No lung markings are seen peripheral to the visceral pleura (green overlay).

The appearance is consistent with a left pneumothorax. There is no evidence of contralateral mediastinal shift, diaphragmatic depression, or ipsilateral intercostal space widening to suggest tension pneumothorax.
questions.hint: This patient’s dyspnea, diminished breath sounds over the left lung base, and homogeneous opacification on chest x-ray are caused by a loss of lung volume.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 1, who gave birth at 39 weeks' gestation via cesarean section under general anesthesia 2 days ago presents with acute chest pain and difficulty breathing. The pregnancy was complicated by hypothyroidism and treated with L-thyroxine. The patient has a history of mild asthma. There is no family history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows cyanosis of the lips. Dull percussion, diminished breathing sounds, and decreased fremitus are heard at the left lung base. An x-ray of the chest shows displacement of fissures and homogeneous opacification of the lower lobe of the left lung. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Fluid accumulation in the alveolar interstitium
Entrance of amniotic fluid into maternal circulation
Chronic inflammation of the respiratory system
Bacterial infection of the alveolar space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Postoperative pulmonary edema with interstitial fluid accumulation is a possible complication after surgery, especially in patients with cardiac disease but also, e.g., after inappropriate volume substitution. As it occurs within the first hour after surgery in most cases and an x-ray would show a bilateral, perihilar haze, peribronchial cuffing, and Kerley B lines, another diagnosis is more likely.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view)

The cardiac silhouette is enlarged (hatched green overlay) and the perihilar air space opacities (green overlay) have a bat wing, or butterfly, configuration. Linear interstitial opacities representing Kerley A lines (orange dashed lines) radiate from the hila to the apices and Kerley B lines (white dashed lines) are seen in the lateral mid zones. The costophrenic angles are blunted (arrows) from bilateral pleural effusions.

These features are characteristically seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema.

B) INCORRECT:

Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a rare but life-threatening condition in the peripartum period that is characterized by respiratory failure and an anaphylactoid response. AFE typically manifests during or shortly after delivery with hypotension, arrhythmias, dyspnea, tachypnea, cyanosis, and altered consciousness. This patient's blood pressure is normal. Additionally, her physical examination and x-ray findings are more consistent with another diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic inflammation of the respiratory system is associated with asthma and COPD, which increase the risk of postoperative pulmonary complications (e.g., atelectasis, pneumonia) in patients undergoing surgery. Although this patient has a history of mild asthma, this does not explain, e.g., the dull percussion note or x-ray findings. An x-ray would show signs of pulmonary hyperinflation that are diffuse and bilateral, rather than opacification limited to one region of the lung.

D) CORRECT:

Cesarean section and general anesthesia are associated with reduced lung compliance, diminished ventilation, retained airway secretions, and postoperative pain resulting in poor cough and shallow breathing, which then increases the risk of atelectasis. The onset of this patient's symptoms within 72 hours of surgery is highly suggestive of postoperative atelectasis. The x-ray findings are consistent with this diagnosis. Deep breathing exercises, directed coughing, and incentive spirometry should be initiated. Suctioning of secretions and/or continuous positive airway pressure may also be beneficial.
Image Description:

Chest x-ray (AP view, supine position)

Mediastinal shift (big arrow) to the left.
Left lung reduced in volume (outline with small arrows). Basal opacities are seen. The left hemidiaphragm is not demarcated.

E) INCORRECT:

General anesthesia and surgery are associated with reduced lung compliance, diminished ventilation, retained airway secretions, and postoperative pain resulting in poor cough and shallow breathing, which then increases the risk of postoperative pneumonia. Postoperative pneumonia typically occurs within 5 days of surgery and manifests with fever, productive cough, and leukocytosis. An x-ray would show pulmonary infiltrates.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (left: PA view; right: lateral view) of a patient with history of pneumonia

Extensive heterogeneous air space consolidation (green overlay) in the left upper lobe abuts part of the major fissure (dashed line). A small pleural effusion is present.

Examples of causes of pulmonary consolidation that can mimic the appearance of infectious pneumonia include organizing pneumonia, malignancy (adenocarcinoma, lymphoma), and pulmonary hemorrhage.

Red: meniscus of pleural effusion

F) INCORRECT:

Acute onset of chest pain and difficulty breathing within 72 hours after surgery, as seen in this patient, should raise suspicion of pulmonary embolism (PE), especially because pregnancy and surgery are important risk factors. However, symptoms of right ventricular strain (e.g., tachycardia, a split second heart sound, and jugular distention) would also be expected. Based on the modified Wells' criteria for PE, this patient has a total score of 1.5 due to recent surgery and immobilization, making PE unlikely (score ≤ 4). Although a chest x-ray may show abnormalities associated with PE (e.g., atelectasis, pleural effusion), these findings are neither sensitive nor specific enough to confirm the diagnosis on their own.
questions.hint: This patient has a common postoperative complication caused by reduced lung compliance and may be asymptomatic or, in more severe cases, present with respiratory distress within 72 hours of surgery.

questions.text:
Two days after undergoing a left hemicolectomy for diverticulitis, a 61-year-old man reports increasing sharp lower chest pain and shortness of breath over the past 24 hours. The pain worsens when he takes a deep breath. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. His current medications include lisinopril, aspirin, metoprolol, and hydromorphone for pain control. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He does not drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. On pulmonary examination, decreased breath sounds are heard over the right lower lung field. Tactile fremitus is decreased. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest shows elevation of the right diaphragm and opacification of the right lower lung zone. Arterial blood gas analysis is most likely to show which of the following findings in this patient?

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum pH with hypoxemia, hypercapnia, and low HCO3- suggests respiratory acidosis and metabolic acidosis, which can be seen in patients with sepsis and advanced acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The metabolic acidosis typically results from underlying sepsis, and with disease progression, patients with ARDS may develop hypercapnic respiratory failure due to respiratory exhaustion. A different acid-base disorder would be expected with atelectasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum pH and hypercapnia suggest respiratory acidosis, which can result from acute hypoventilation due to general anesthesia (e.g., respiratory muscle paralysis, sedative overdose), upper airway obstruction (e.g., laryngeal edema, blocked endotracheal tube), or an acute exacerbation of COPD or asthma, in which diffuse small airway obstruction occurs. A different acid-base disorder would be expected with the regional alveolar collapse characteristic of atelectasis.

C) INCORRECT:

Decreased serum pH and low HCO3- suggest metabolic acidosis, which can occur during or after surgery and manifest with an elevated anion gap (e.g., lactic acidosis due to tissue hypoperfusion) or a normal anion gap (e.g., excessive saline infusion). A different acid-base disorder would be expected with atelectasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Increased pH with hypocapnia indicates respiratory alkalosis. Hyperoxemia with respiratory alkalosis suggests mechanical ventilation with an inappropriately high FiO2 and tidal volume as the most likely etiology. In a patient with atelectasis, hypoxemia would be expected.

E) CORRECT:

Postoperative atelectasis is one of the most common pulmonary complications in the first 72 hours after surgery. After chest or abdominal surgery, inadequately controlled postoperative pain discourages deep breathing (which is important for alveolar recruitment at the lung bases) and impairs coughing (which can lead to mucus plugging in an airway and absorption atelectasis). Patients subsequently develop regional alveolar collapse and hypoxemia from a ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch as well as a right-to-left pulmonary shunt in the area of atelectasis.

To compensate for the resulting hypoxemia, the patient hyperventilates to increase ventilation of the noncollapsed alveoli and often develops respiratory alkalosis (high pH, low pCO2). Hypoxemia due to a right-to-left pulmonary shunt cannot be improved by 100% O2 delivery; instead, alveolar recruitment needs to be facilitated using adequate analgesia and lung expansion maneuvers.
questions.hint: This patient's recent history of abdominal surgery, examination findings (diminished breath sounds and decreased tactile fremitus over the affected lung), and chest x-ray findings (opacification of the right lower lung zone with ipsilateral elevation of the diaphragm) indicate postoperative atelectasis.

questions.text:
Two days after undergoing left hemicolectomy for a colonic mass, a 60-year-old man develops shortness of breath. His temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds and decreased fremitus at both lung bases. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH
7.35


PaO2
70 mm Hg


PCO2

40 mm Hg


An x-ray of the chest shows collapse of the bases of both lungs. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's hypoxemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anatomic dead space refers to the proportion of the airway that does not participate in gas exchange (e.g., nasopharynx, trachea). Anatomic dead space is not affected by atelectasis and would not explain this patient's hypoxemia.

B) INCORRECT:

A decreased hemoglobin oxygen-binding capacity (e.g., due to carbon monoxide poisoning or methemoglobinemia) can cause hypoxemia. However, atelectasis does not affect hemoglobin oxygen-binding capacity.

C) INCORRECT:

An increased tidal volume would result in increased ventilation and improved oxygenation, rather than hypoxemia, as seen in this patient. Exercises to increase tidal volume (e.g., using an incentive spirometer) are commonly used to prevent and correct atelectasis.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with bibasilar atelectasis, collapsed alveoli are unable to participate in gas exchange, allowing venous blood to pass into the arterial circulation without becoming oxygenated, which results in a right-to-left pulmonary shunt and ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch.

A right-to-left pulmonary shunt or a V/Q mismatch increases the A-a gradient, which is ≈ 150 - (1.25 × PaCO2) - PaO2 on room air (i.e., FiO2 of 0.21) and at sea level. The normal A-a gradient for age should be < (age in years / 4) + 4. This patient's A-a gradient should be < 19 mm Hg but is 30 mm Hg.

E) INCORRECT:

The rate of oxygen consumption is increased in states of high-energy expenditure (e.g., exercise, severe illness, sepsis) and usually leads to a compensatory increase in ventilation (e.g., increase in respiratory rate and/or tidal volume) to prevent hypoxemia. This patient does not have any history to suggest increased oxygen consumption.

F) INCORRECT:

Decreased chest wall compliance (e.g., due to scoliosis, trauma, or frailty) can lead to hypoxemia as a result of impaired ventilation and may occur parallel to atelectasis. However, hypercapnia would also be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's dyspnea and decreased bilateral fremitus in the early postoperative period (1–3 days after surgery) are concerning for bibasilar atelectasis, which is confirmed with a chest x-ray showing collapsed lung.

questions.text: Eight hours after undergoing successful cholecystectomy, a 65-year-old man with scoliosis complains of shortness of breath. Respirations are 28/min and pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Physical examination shows kyphotic deformation of the thorax. Cardiopulmonary examination shows intercostal retractions and diminished breath sounds on the left side. There is trace pedal edema bilaterally. An x-ray of the chest shows bilateral fluffy infiltrates, and the cardiac silhouette is shifted slightly to the left side. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's hypoxia?

choices.text: Air trapped in the pleural space

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia can also manifest with dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxia, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation. Although his post-operative status increases the risk of developing a nosocomial infection, the acute onset and lack of fever, malaise, and purulent sputum make this diagnosis unlikely. Moreover, pneumonia typically has a space-occupying effect on x-ray, which is not consistent with this patient's volume loss seen on x-ray.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA and lateral views) of a patient with pneumonia

There is heterogeneous right upper lobe consolidation (green overlay) with air bronchograms (examples of bronchial walls indicated by white lines). The major (white dashed line) and minor fissures (red dashed lines) are elevated from normal position as a result of accompanying atelectasis. No hilar enlargement or pleural effusion is seen.

The differential diagnosis for airspace consolidation considers the radiographic appearance, associated findings (e.g., lymphadenopathy, pleural effusion), and patient history and symptoms. Pneumonia, hemorrhage, edema, tumor, and protein can all present as consolidation on a chest radiograph.

Green line: aortic arch margin; LL: lower lobe; ML: middle lobe; UL: upper lobe

B) CORRECT:

This patient's symptoms and x-ray findings are suggestive of atelectasis, which is one of the most common postoperative complications and results from the collapsing of alveoli. This patient's decreased breath sounds on the left and slight mediastinal shift to the left are consistent with atelectasis that is worse on the left side (e.g., left-sided volume loss). Risk factors for atelectasis include immobility, recent surgery, and conditions that reduce aeration to the lungs (e.g., kyphosis, scoliosis).
Image Description:

X-ray chest (AP view)

Suboptimal aeration has resulted in areas of ill-defined opacification in both lungs (example indicated by red overlay). Additionally, there is marked opacification of the retrocardiac lower left lung (green circle), with non-visualization of left lower lobe pulmonary vessels and obscuration of the margin of the left hemidiaphragm (indicated by dashed line). The overall volume of the left lung is reduced; the distance between ribs (indicated by black and white double-arrows) is smaller on the left than right, and the cardiac silhouette is positioned slightly to the left of normal (indicated by dashed and continuous lines and arrows) despite good positioning of the patient (similar distance between spinous processes and medial clavicles bilaterally; yellow overlay).

The above findings indicate the presence of atelectasis, which is marked in the lower left lung. Clinical parameters would help exclude concomitant pneumonia or aspiration.

Blue overlay: ECG pads

C) INCORRECT:

Signs of acute PE may include acute shortness of breath, hypoxemia, and possibly decreased breath sounds. However, this patient lacks any signs of DVT (e.g., unilateral leg swelling) and the slight mediastinal shift to the affected side suggests an intraparenchymal process.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with pleuritic chest pain

A peripheral opacity (Hampton hump; green overlay) obscures the adjacent margin of the right hemidiaphragm. A Hampton hump is subpleural and is caused by pulmonary hemorrhage or infarction. The appearance is often wedge-shaped; however, it can alternatively be dome-shaped, if the apex is spared as a result of collateral bronchial arterial blood flow.

The differential diagnosis includes pneumonia and malignancy. Of note, the greater distance between the spinous processes and the medial edge of the clavicle on the right compared to the left indicates that the patient is rotated slightly to the right. The distances will be nearly equal when a patient is not rotated, whereas widening will be seen on the side to which a patient is rotated.

Dashed lines: margins of medial clavicles; White line and ellipses: spinous processes

D) INCORRECT:

Pleural effusion can also manifest with dyspnea and tachypnea, as seen in this patient. However, this patient's x-ray shows bilateral fluffy infiltrates, which are not consistent with a pleural effusion. Findings consistent with pleural effusion include presence of a homogeneous density within the pleural space, blunting of the costophrenic angles, and a meniscus sign. Furthermore, this patient's mediastinal shift towards the affected side is not consistent with pleural effusion, which would typically cause a shift to the contralateral side (e.g., space-occupying process)
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with tamoxifen-induced acute eosinophilic pneumonia

Peribronchial thickening (examples circled in yellow) and linear parenchymal opacities (examples indicated by white lines) are evidence of interstitial lung disease. A small pleural effusion (red line) projects through the right hemidiaphragm and blunts the right lateral costophrenic sulcus. A normal costophrenic sulcus is typically seen as an acutely angled junction between the costal and diaphragmatic pleural reflections (white dashed line).

Right chest wall staples (examples indicated by black overlays) and breast asymmetry (green outline) are the result of a recent mastectomy and reconstruction.

E) INCORRECT:

Air entrapment in the pleural space is consistent with tension pneumothorax. Although patients with tension pneumothorax can also present with sudden-onset shortness of breath and hypoxemia, x-ray findings would show lung hyperlucency instead of the bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. This patient's postoperative status and loss of lung volume on x-ray suggest a different etiology of his symptoms.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (PA view)

A large right tension pneumothorax is accompanied by lung collapse. When compared to the left hemithorax, no lung markings are seen in the right hemithorax beyond the margin of the collapsed right lung (green overlay). Signs of tension seen here include contralateral shift of mediastinal structures and depression of the right hemidiaphragm (indicated by red lines and arrow). Another sign that may be seen in tension pneumothorax is ipsilateral intercostal space widening.

An unrelated finding on this radiograph is slight curvature of the upper to midthoracic spine, convex to the left.

Black line and arrows: shift of mediastinal pleura; white line and arrows: shift of cardiomediastinal silhouette
questions.hint: Dyspnea, hypoxemia, diminished breath sounds, and mediastinal shift towards the affected side in this postoperative patient are suggestive of lung volume loss.

questions.text: One day after undergoing an open appendectomy for a perforated appendix, a 63-year-old man develops cough and difficulty breathing. He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease well controlled with albuterol and ipratropium inhalers. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He does not drink alcohol. He is currently receiving intravenous cefepime, metronidazole, and morphine. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. Pulse oxygenation on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 93%. Examination shows rapid and shallow breathing, reduced breath sounds, dullness to percussion, and absent tactile fremitus over the right lung base. An x-ray of the chest shows loss of lung volume and a wedge-shaped opacity in the right lower hemithorax. CT pulmonary angiogram does not show any filling defects. Which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's condition?

choices.text: Elevation of the head of the bed to 30° after surgery
Additional dose of bronchodilators before and after surgery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevation of the head of the bed to 30° postoperatively reduces the risk of aspiration pneumonia, which manifests with tachypnea, dullness to percussion, and opacification on chest x-ray, most commonly the right lung. However, while surgery is a risk factor for developing aspiration pneumonia, additional symptoms (e.g., fever, cough, purulent sputum production) would be expected. Moreover, aspiration pneumonia is not associated with a decrease in tactile fremitus because pneumonia causes a dense consolidation, which increases tactile fremitus.

B) INCORRECT:

Patients with COPD may need additional doses of an inhaled rapid-acting beta-agonist (e.g., albuterol) before and after surgery to prevent postoperative bronchospasm, which is more common in patients with COPD. However, bronchospasm is not associated with tachypnea, diminished breath sounds, or dullness to percussion. Moreover, bronchospasm is usually associated with wheezing and coughing, which are not seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Intraoperative ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) provides positive pressure to the lungs, which reduces alveolar collapse by stenting open the airways, thereby reducing the risk of postoperative atelectasis.

Postoperatively, lung expansion maneuvers that increase PEEP can also be used, such as continuous positive airway pressure or incentive spirometry. Other strategies to prevent postoperative atelectasis include deep breathing exercises, adequate pain control, and early mobilization.

D) INCORRECT:

Although intravenous opiates can increase the risk of respiratory depression, thereby increasing the risk of pulmonary complications, this patient is tachypneic, so it is not necessary to stop morphine at this time. Additionally, optimal postoperative pain control allows the patient to practice deep breathing, which keeps the lungs expanded and helps to prevent atelectasis.

E) INCORRECT:

Injections of low-molecular-weight heparin are used to prevent postoperative deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). Patients with PE may present with tachypnea, hypoxemia, and a wedge-shaped opacity on chest x-ray. However, CT pulmonary angiography in a patient with PE would demonstrate filling defects, which are not seen here. Moreover, DVT and PE generally occur on postoperative day five, while this patient is on postoperative day one.
questions.hint: This patient's reduced breath sounds, dullness to percussion, and absent tactile fremitus in combination with a wedge-shaped opacity in the right lower hemithorax on chest x-ray (which corresponds to a collapsed right lower lobe) one day after surgery suggest postoperative atelectasis.

questions.text: One day after undergoing a Whipple procedure for treatment of pancreatic adenocarcinoma, a 73-year-old man develops a cough and difficulty breathing in the intensive care unit. He is mechanically ventilated with supplemental oxygen. He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 24/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows reduced breath sounds and absent tactile fremitus over the left hemithorax. An x-ray of the chest shows loss of lung volume, a moderate mediastinal shift to the left, and a wedge-shaped opacity in the left lower lobe. Positive end-expiratory pressure is increased to 8 cm H2O. Three days later, an x-ray of the chest shows normal findings. Which of the following best explains this patient's pulmonary findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A simple pneumothorax can occur in mechanically ventilated patients and manifest with difficulty breathing, hypoxemia, reduced breath sounds, and absent tactile fremitus on the affected side. However, chest x-ray would not show a wedge-shaped opacity, as seen here, but rather reduced or absent lung markings beyond a pleural line. Finally, pneumothoraces in mechanically ventilated patients are often caused by barotrauma from high PEEP, so this patient's improvement after increasing PEEP would not be consistent with this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax manifests with difficulty breathing, hypoxemia, reduced breath sounds, and absent tactile fremitus on the affected side in patients who are mechanically ventilated. However, additional symptoms of tension pneumothorax such as tachycardia, hypotension, jugular venous distension, and contralateral deviation of the trachea are absent in this patient. Moreover, a chest x-ray would show reduced or absent lung markings with a mediastinal shift to the contralateral rather than the affected side. Finally, pneumothoraces in mechanically ventilated patients are often caused by barotrauma from high PEEP, so this patient's improvement after increasing PEEP is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia is a common postoperative complication that manifests with difficulty breathing and hypoxemia. Pneumonia will appear as an opacity on chest x-ray, and, if the consolidation obstructs a small airway, can even show evidence of volume loss, as seen here. However, fever, crackles, and increased rather than absent tactile fremitus would be expected in a patient presenting with pneumonia. Finally, increased PEEP is not a treatment for pneumonia and may even worsen oxygenation, whereas this patient's pulmonary findings were markedly improved in 3 days.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's hypoxemia and absent tactile fremitus in combination with chest x-ray findings of lobar collapse on postoperative day 1 suggest atelectasis. His improvement, as visualized by the normal chest x-ray days after increasing PEEP, further supports this diagnosis. Postoperative pain can interfere with spontaneous deep breathing and coughing, which can lead to hypoxemia and airway collapse. Further, airway obstruction (due to retained pulmonary secretions) leads to resorption of gas by pulmonary capillaries, which can cause the collapse of nonventilated alveoli distal to the bronchial occlusion (i.e., resorptive atelectasis). However, increased positive pressure can reopen the collapsed alveoli by stenting open the airways, providing the lung expansion that the patient is unable to achieve by themself. Patients who smoke and/or have COPD, like this patient, are particularly at risk for postoperative atelectasis. Preoperative smoking cessation and medical optimization are key to prevention.

Other types of atelectasis include nonobstructive and rounded.

X-ray chest (a: PA view; b: lateral view)

A poorly marginated opacity (arrow) obscures part of the right heart border on the PA view. On the lateral view, it is seen as a wedge-shaped opacity coursing anteroinferiorily from the hilum, sharply demarcated superiorly by the depressed minor fissure (m) and inferiorly by the elevated right major fissure (M).

E) INCORRECT:

Pleural effusion manifests with difficulty breathing, cough, hypoxemia, reduced breath sounds, and reduced tactile fremitus on the affected side. However, a chest x-ray would show blunting of the left costophrenic angle, and, in the case of a very large effusion, the mediastinum would shift to the contralateral (not the ipsilateral) side. Moreover, increased PEEP is not a treatment of pleural effusion.

F) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary embolism can occur in the postoperative setting and manifests with difficulty breathing, cough, and hypoxemia. However, patients with pulmonary embolism typically have pleuritic chest pain. Moreover, decreased breath sounds and decreased tactile fremitus are not common features of pulmonary embolism. Finally, increased PEEP is not a treatment of pulmonary embolism.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents to the emergency department with fevers, chills, and cough for the past 24 hours. The patient has had several pneumonias, all on the left side.
A chest radiograph is notable for a left lower lobe air-space filling process. A CT scan of the chest with contrast reveals an area of dense consolidation in the left lower lobe that is associated with an anomalous blood vessel originating from the thoracic aorta. The remainder of the study is unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A congenital pulmonary airway malformation (previously called congenital cystic adenomatoid malformation) manifests as air-fluid filled cysts in the posterobasal segments of the lower lobes.

B) INCORRECT:

A tracheal diverticulum, or out-pouching of the trachea, is usually visible at the thoracic inlet on CT scan.

C) INCORRECT:

Bronchial atresia should be suspected when there is proximal bronchial obstruction by a mucocele, in addition to isolated emphysematous changes distal to the obstruction.

D) INCORRECT:

Bronchogenic cysts are usually mediastinal in location and are almost always solitary.

E) CORRECT:

Adults occasionally present with congenital lung disorders that have not been diagnosed previously.

A bronchopulmonary sequestration is a section of nonfunctional lung tissue that is not connected to the tracheobronchial tree and does not receive its blood supply from the pulmonary circulation. It can manifest as a large, vascular, lower lobe consolidation. In two-thirds of patients, an anomalous systemic artery is visible on CT scan; however, additional imaging with MRI may be required to confirm the diagnosis. The anomalous vessel usually originates from the thoracic aorta; however, it may also originate from the abdominal aorta or the coronary arteries. Sequestrations generally do not communicate directly with the upper airway. However, bacteria may gain access to the sequestration through lower pulmonary connections, causing recurrent pneumonias.

Key learning point: The congenital lung disorder of bronchopulmonary sequestration typically manifests with recurrent pneumonia.

questions.text: One day after undergoing a Whipple procedure, a 73-year-old man develops a cough and difficulty breathing in the intensive care unit. He is mechanically ventilated with supplemental oxygen. He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 24/min and shallow, and blood pressure is 122/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. Examination shows reduced breath sounds and absent tactile fremitus over the left hemithorax. An x-ray of the chest shows loss of lung volume and a moderate mediastinal shift to the left. Positive end-expiratory pressure is increased to 8 cm H2O. Three days later, an x-ray of the chest shows normal findings. Which of the following best explains this patient's pulmonary findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A simple pneumothorax can occur in mechanically ventilated patients and manifest with difficulty breathing, hypoxemia, reduced breath sounds, and absent tactile fremitus on the affected side. However, chest x-ray would not show a wedge-shaped opacity, as seen here, but rather reduced or absent lung markings beyond a pleural line. Finally, pneumothoraces in mechanically ventilated patients are often caused by barotrauma from high PEEP, so this patient's improvement after increasing PEEP would not be consistent with this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Tension pneumothorax manifests with difficulty breathing, hypoxemia, reduced breath sounds, and absent tactile fremitus on the affected side in patients who are mechanically ventilated. However, additional symptoms of tension pneumothorax such as tachycardia, hypotension, jugular venous distension, and contralateral deviation of the trachea are absent in this patient. Moreover, a chest x-ray would show reduced or absent lung markings with a mediastinal shift to the contralateral rather than the affected side. Finally, pneumothoraces in mechanically ventilated patients are often caused by barotrauma from high PEEP, so this patient's improvement after increasing PEEP is inconsistent with this diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's hypoxemia and absent tactile fremitus in combination with chest x-ray findings of lobar collapse on postoperative day 1 suggest atelectasis. His improvement, as visualized by the normal chest x-ray days after increasing PEEP, further supports this diagnosis. Postoperative pain can interfere with spontaneous deep breathing and coughing, which can lead to hypoxemia and airway collapse. Further, airway obstruction (due to retained pulmonary secretions) leads to resorption of gas by pulmonary capillaries, which can cause the collapse of nonventilated alveoli distal to the bronchial occlusion (i.e., resorptive atelectasis). However, increased positive pressure can reopen the collapsed alveoli by stenting open the airways, providing the lung expansion that the patient is unable to achieve by themself. Patients who smoke and/or have COPD, like this patient, are particularly at risk for postoperative atelectasis. Preoperative smoking cessation and medical optimization are key to prevention.

Other types of atelectasis include nonobstructive and rounded.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with advanced colon adenocarcinoma complains of right upper quadrant pain. He has rising carcinoembryonic antigen levels. Where is the most likely site of metastatic disease?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lung metastases can occur in advanced colon adenocarcinoma, but the liver is typically the first site of metastasis due to portal venous drainage. The patient's symptoms and rising carcinoembryonic antigen levels suggest liver involvement rather than lung metastasis, which would not typically cause right upper quadrant pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Brain metastases from colon adenocarcinoma are uncommon and usually occur with widespread disease, often presenting with neurological deficits. The patient's right upper quadrant pain and rising carcinoembryonic antigen levels are more indicative of liver metastasis, given the typical metastatic pattern of colon cancer.

C) INCORRECT:

Bone metastases are rare in colon adenocarcinoma, which typically spreads via the portal venous system to the liver. The patient's symptoms and rising carcinoembryonic antigen levels suggest liver involvement rather than skeletal metastasis, which would present with localized bone pain or fractures.

D) CORRECT:

Colonic malignancies predominantly metastasize to the liver due to the portal venous system, which drains blood from the colon directly into the liver. Tumor cells entering this pathway are filtered by the liver, creating a favorable environment for metastasis. The patient's right upper quadrant pain and rising carcinoembryonic antigen levels, a marker for tumor burden, strongly suggest hepatic involvement. The liver is the primary site of metastatic spread in colon cancer.

Key learning point: The liver is the most common site of metastasis for colonic malignancies due to portal circulation drainage. Basal atelectasis is a common cause of hypoxia shortly after upper abdominal surgery due to shallow breathing and alveolar collapse.

questions.text:
Two days after you perform a left hemicolectomy for a colonic mass, a 60-year-old man develops shortness of breath. His temperature is 38.1°C, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 88%. On cardiopulmonary examination, there are decreased breath sounds and decreased fremitus at both lung bases. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:


pH, arterial blood
7.35 (7.38–7.46)


Po2, arterial blood

70 mm Hg (83–116)


Pco2, arterial blood

40 mm Hg (32–45)


A chest x-ray shows collapse of the bases of both lungs. Which one of the following is the most likely mechanism of his hypoxemia?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decreased chest wall compliance (e.g., due to scoliosis, trauma, or frailty) can lead to hypoxemia as a result of impaired ventilation and may occur parallel to atelectasis. However, hypercapnia would also be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

A decreased hemoglobin oxygen-binding capacity (e.g., due to carbon monoxide poisoning or methemoglobinemia) can cause hypoxemia. However, atelectasis does not affect hemoglobin oxygen-binding capacity.

C) INCORRECT:

Anatomic dead space refers to the proportion of the airway that does not participate in gas exchange (e.g., nasopharynx, trachea). Anatomic dead space is not affected by atelectasis and would not explain this patient's hypoxemia.

D) CORRECT:

In patients with bibasilar atelectasis, collapsed alveoli are unable to participate in gas exchange, allowing venous blood to pass into the arterial circulation without becoming oxygenated, which results in a right-to-left pulmonary shunt and ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatch.

A right-to-left pulmonary shunt or a V/Q mismatch increases the A-a gradient, which is ≈ 150 - (1.25 × PaCO2) - PaO2 on room air (i.e., FiO2 of 0.21) and at sea level. The normal A-a gradient for age should be < (age in years / 4) + 4. This patient's A-a gradient should be < 19 mm Hg but is 30 mm Hg.

Key learning point: Atelectasis causes hypoxemia by reducing the number of ventilated alveoli, leading to right-to-left shunting and ventilation-perfusion mismatch.

E) INCORRECT:

An increased tidal volume would result in increased ventilation and improved oxygenation, rather than hypoxemia, as seen in this patient. Exercises to increase tidal volume (e.g., using an incentive spirometer) are commonly used to prevent and correct atelectasis.
questions.hint: This patient's dyspnea and decreased bilateral fremitus in the early postoperative period (1–3 days after surgery) are concerning for bibasilar atelectasis, which is confirmed with a chest x-ray showing collapsed lung.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman is evaluated on postoperative day 2 following an open cholecystectomy. She has mild shortness of breath and has been reluctant to use her incentive spirometer due to incisional pain. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Her BMI is 34 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 22/min. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion in the lower right hemithorax. The surgical incision appears clean and without drainage. Her calves are non-tender and without swelling. Chest x-ray is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation of tachypnea and physical exam findings of decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion after a surgical procedure, together with a chest x-ray showing right lower-lobe collapse, indicate postoperative atelectasis, which most commonly occurs within 72 hours of surgery. Risk factors include upper abdominal surgery, obesity, a history of smoking, and poor lung expansion due to incisional pain. The resulting shallow breathing leads to alveolar collapse, particularly at the lung bases. This creates a ventilation-perfusion mismatch, causing hypoxemia. Prevention and treatment are centered on lung expansion therapies, such as incentive spirometry and early ambulation.

B) INCORRECT:

A pulmonary embolism can cause postoperative shortness of breath, tachycardia, and hypoxemia. However, lung examination is typically clear on auscultation. This patient's findings of decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion point towards a parenchymal lung process rather than a vascular obstruction. Additionally, this patient's x-ray findings suggest right lower-lobe collapse, which is not characteristic of pulmonary embolism.

C) INCORRECT:

A perioperative myocardial infarction (MI) can present with shortness of breath and tachycardia due to the stress of surgery. However, an MI would not typically cause the specific lung examination findings of decreased breath sounds and dullness to percussion. The clinical picture is more consistent with a different etiology.

D) INCORRECT:

Aspiration pneumonia is a potential postoperative complication but typically presents after postoperative day 3, as the infection develops. While it causes hypoxemia, physical examination would more likely reveal rales (crackles) or signs of consolidation, rather than the basilar decreased breath sounds and dullness seen here. Additionally, this patient's x-ray shows right lower-lobe collapse, not a consolidation.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man is two days post laparotomy for diverticular disease. He reports increasing shortness of breath and mild right-sided chest discomfort. Physical examination reveals decreased air entry at the right lung base. Vital signs are otherwise stable (see report).


Temperature
37.8°C


Oxygen saturation
92% on room air


Chest X-ray: Platelike opacity in the right lower lobe
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics are considered for postoperative pulmonary infections. However, the patient's mild symptoms, slight temperature elevation, and platelike opacity on chest x-ray suggest atelectasis rather than pneumonia. Pneumonia typically presents with higher fever, productive cough, and lobar consolidation, which are absent here.

B) INCORRECT:

A ventilation-perfusion scan is used to diagnose pulmonary embolism, especially with a normal chest x-ray. The platelike opacity in this patient suggests atelectasis, common after abdominal surgery, rather than embolism. The opacity affects the scan's reliability, and the patient's stable vital signs make embolism unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Chest tube insertion is indicated for significant pleural air or fluid accumulation, such as pneumothorax or hemothorax. The patient's symptoms and chest x-ray findings suggest atelectasis, not pleural pathology. Atelectasis presents as a linear opacity, not requiring invasive drainage like a chest tube.

D) CORRECT:

Postoperative atelectasis is common due to reduced lung expansion from pain, anesthesia, and immobility. Incentive spirometry encourages deep inspirations, recruiting collapsed alveoli and promoting lung expansion. The platelike opacity on the chest x-ray indicates localized alveolar collapse, typical in dependent lung areas post-surgery. Incentive spirometry increases transpulmonary pressure, aiding alveolar opening and reducing complications like pneumonia. Regular use optimizes oxygenation and prevents hypoventilation and atelectasis.

Key learning point: Postoperative atelectasis is common after abdominal surgery and can be managed effectively with incentive spirometry to encourage deep breathing and lung expansion.
